sub_title: Assistant Professor of Sustainability Governance in the Developing World
summary:
Assistant Professor at the Copernicus Institute of Sustainable Development. Research on multilevel sustainability governance in the Global South, focusing on policy coherence around the Sustainable Development Goals and climate goals in Africa and Asia. Leading an NWO research project on water-energy-food nexus governance and social justice in South Africa. 

Academic Director at Utrecht University for the European Universities Initiative CHARM-EU, representing Utrecht University in the Academic Council. Program leader of the joint degree Master's Global Challenges for Sustainability. Lead in developing and coordinating the Capstone, the final phase of the Master's with a transdisciplinary team-based thesis project.

Broad range of expertise in multilevel sustainability governance, including in the areas of climate, forests, agriculture, REDD+ and extractive industries. Focus on international negotiations and politics, national policy-making, and on-the-ground projects in developing countries. Extensive experience in research, teaching, grant acquisition, coordinating collaborative projects and managing multi-stakeholder processes.

For more information and contact details: https://www.uu.nl/staff/mobile/mjvijge

projects.title: Water-Energy-Food communities in South Africa: multi-actor nexus governance for social justice?  NWO-WOTRO grant Cooperation South Africa-The Netherlands
projects.description: The Water-Energy-Food (WEF) nexus is gaining scholarly and policy attention. Despite growing evidence on which type of nexus governance works, little is known about the consequences of such governance for social justice. Implementing the nexus requires decision-making about trade-offs between the use and production of water, energy and food, which are particularly acute at household and community levels. This raises justice questions of whether the nexus can benefit all, and who makes decisions and at what levels. In South Africa, where access to water, energy and food are strongly influenced by a history of Apartheid and inequality, there is a need to study the challenges and opportunities of a socially just nexus implementation from the bottom up. This research introduces the concept of WEF communities, inspired by EU legislation for energy communities to produce their own renewable electricity. We study how similar communities in South Africa could be legally recognised and expanded to include water use and food production, and with what consequences for social justice, particularly for the poorest and women. Incorporation of WEF communities in South Africa’s legal frameworks may enhance social justice from the bottom up, yet this is uncertain given inequalities in (legal) access to energy, water and land. The project consists of (comparative) analyses of legal frameworks in the EU and South Africa, as well as household assessments on WEF interlinkages and decision-making in two communities in the Eastern Cape and Northern Cape. Data is collected through literature review, surveys, focus group discussions, interviews and fieldshops. Through active participation in the research, stakeholders from the community to the national level will build capacity and connections, including through a training of trainers' programme targeting the poor, women and youth. Outreach happens through publications, workshops, a website, a symposium and local WEF nexus festivals.

Assistant Professor of Sustainability Governance in the Developing World

profile_positions.description:
Assistant Professor of Sustainability Governance in the Developing World, Environmental Governance group, Copernicus Institute of Sustainable Development, Utrecht University. My research analyses policy coherence of sustainability challenges in developing countries. I particularly focus on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, including through the GlobalGoals research project at Utrecht University (https://globalgoalsproject.eu). I am Principal Investigator in an NWO-WOTRO research project on the water-energy-food nexus in South Africa (https://wefcommunities.co.za). In addition, I am part of a research project led by the Stockholm Environment Institute on the (in)coherence between climate action and the Sustainable Development Goals and the implications for inequality in the Global North and South. I currently co-supervise 7 PhD students on my research topic.

Besides teaching and coordinating BSc and MSc courses, I have a leading role in the curriculum development of the Master's programme Global Challenges for Sustainability at the European Universities Initiative CHARM-EU (https://charm-eu.eu/masters/globalchallenges), where I act as Utrecht Academic Director, programme leader and work package leader of Public Engagement in TORCH (https://charm-eu.eu/torch).
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description:
In 2023, CHARM-EU started a new phase with an ambitious expansion to all forms of higher education (BSc, MSc, PhD, professional) and 4 additional partners. As Academic Director at Utrecht University, I co-develop and coordinate the strategy and content of CHARM-EU education and research within and beyond my university.

CHARM-EU is a European Universities Initiative funded by the European Commission that serves as a testbed university for innovations in challenge-based and transdisciplinary education and research around sustainability. It is a collaboration between Utrecht University, University of Barcelona, Trinity College Dublin, University of Montpellier, Eötvos Loránd University Budapest, recently joined by Åbo Akademi University, Würzburg University, University of Bergen and Hochschule Ruhr West. For more information, see https://www.charm-eu.eu.
profile_positions.title: Academic Director

profile_positions.description: Utrecht programme leader and Academic Coordinator of CHARM-EU's Master programme 'Global Challenges for Sustainability'. This includes: representing Utrecht University in the Academic Board, coordinator of the Capstone, co-coordinator of the module 'Sustainability', work package co-lead of CHARM-EU's external engagement strategy, selection of students, and recruitment of Utrecht CHARM-EU staff. Next to taking leading roles in the development and management of CHARM-EU's education, I am leader of the Work Package Public Engagement in CHARM-EU's research component TORCH
profile_positions.title: Academic Coordinator
Climate Policy Expert

company.name: Myanmar Centre for Economic and Social Development

profile_positions.company: Myanmar Centre for Economic and Social Development
profile_positions.description:
The promises and perils of the transparency turn: can the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative help Myanmar on its way to a sustainable democracy?

1-year Niels Stensen Fellowship. My research analysed the governance of Myanmar's extractive industries sector, with a particular focus on whether the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) leads to a more sustainable and democratic governance of the sector. As visiting fellow with the Myanmar Centre for Economic and Social Development (CESD) I have been involved in an assessment of socio-economic impacts of Myanmar's artisanal jade mining, and of opportunities to legalise the sector. I also carried out an evaluation of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative in Myanmar and provided community training on addressing impacts from extractive industries in Myanmar.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
The UNDP-UNEP Poverty-Environment Initiative is a joint UN programme to mainstream environmental issues in development policy and planning of developing countries. 

As advisor and field researcher with the UNDP, I helped coordinate and execute an integrated assessment of social, environmental and economic impacts of gold and limestone mining, and provided recommendations to assess and address such impacts in Mandalay, Myanmar. The project involves a taskforce of government, civil society and private sector representatives to stimulate joint learning and the co-production of data.
profile_positions.title: Adviser and Field Researcher UNDP-UNEP Poverty-Environment Initiative

profile_positions.description:
Carbonizing forest governance: Analyzing the consequences of REDD+ for multilevel forest governance

Full scholarship from Wageningen School of Social Sciences. My thesis analyses the consequences of REDD+ for multilevel forest governance. The thesis contains an analysis of global REDD+ debates, two in-depth case studies on REDD+ in India, and a comparative analysis of seven REDD+ countries. It argues that REDD+ manifests itself differently at different levels of governance, with varying consequences for multilevel forest governance. Global policy debates around REDD+ mainly focus on results-based compensation for carbon emission reductions, to be measured by experts with the use of national monitoring systems. In line with this, many national REDD+ policy documents plan to make national government agencies responsible for REDD+. This might promote a centralisation of authority. In contrast to the global level, REDD+ at national and project level is often framed as a policy mechanism to generate not only carbon but also non-carbon benefits, to be measured by both experts and local communities. At the moment, however, countries (still) lack the capacity to monitor such non-carbon benefits and engage in community-based monitoring.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description: Main lecturer and course coordinator for MSc course International Environmental Policy. Teaching assistant or guest lecturer in MSc course International Environmental Policy; MSc course Environmental Policy Analysis and Evaluation; MSc course Climate Governance; MSc course Design of Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies; International course on Climate change adaptation and mitigation as institutional change process; and BSc course Governance for Forest, Nature and Biodiversity.
profile_positions.title: Main Lecturer, Teaching Assistant and Guest Lecturer

profile_positions.description: Main supervisor or second reader of nine MSc theses in Environmental Policy
profile_positions.title: Co-supervisor and Second Reader of MSc Theses

Main tasks: analysis and establishment of the network; liaison with university departments and partners outside the university; organisation of workshops, public events and meetings; contribution to funding and research proposals; communication and outreach
